w:r.w:t: Conventions for Running Euryale jobs on the Grid

system is a system to accomplish a simple-sounding but surprisingly complex task: Run workflows in The Grid. While many such tools exist today, Euryale features the following specific characteristics: It uses a deferred planning (late binding) approach, adding fault tolerance through re-planning. Each job is treated in isolation of other jobs, minimizing interference between jobs. Euryale generates Condor-G jobs and interfaces with Condor’s DAGMan workflow manager, exploiting particular strengths of DAGMan.
shows a Yourdon Flow Chart with data- and control flows. The key players are the
. The majority of the Euryale logic resides in these three components. Each will be described in a section of its own.

The flow chart shows data storage used by the system between parallel lines. Actors of the Euryale system are shown in rounded boxes, whereas external actors are shown in square boxes. Data flows are shown by solid lines whereas controls flows use dashed lines. Shown in disk shape are VDS catalogs. Elements that were repeated in the diagram are marked with an asterisk. Shown in blue are the higher-level wrappers.
The user usually provides the DAX file as argument to
tool reads the DAX file, properties and a submit file template to produce the Condor submit files and DAGMan’s DAG file.
will submit the workflow do Condor DAGMan. DAGMan will decide which jobs first to run, and start for each ready job, up to a threshold, a PRE script before the job, and a
after the job. The heavy lifting happens in the
makes use of data supplied by the
is responsible for the following items:
It calls out to the external site selector.
It rewrites the submit file for the chosen site.
It creates the setup and cleanup script for the job.
It runs the setup job on the remote site to prepare for the job.
It creates the lists of input- and output files.
It transfers necessary input files to that site.
It deals with re-planning upon failures.

After the pre script ran, DAGMan submits the job, described in the submit file rewritten by the pre script, to Condor. Condor in turn will run the job on the Grid. Once Condor detected that the job finished, regardless of remote failures, the
is responsible for the following items:
It starts the remote cleanup job.
It checks on the successful completion of the remote job.
it finishes early, signaling failure to DAGMan.
It transfers output files to the collection area.
It registers produced files in the replica manager.
In terms of grid interactions, each Euryale job goes through the same steps of a linear workflow, called a
Setup the remote job directory and linking existing input files. The setup job runs on the job manager for the
. The setup job is run synchronously through
party transfers controlled from the submit host. This uses either
Let Condor-G run the compute job.
Create deep directories on the output storage element, if
was found. Otherwise, out filenames are flattened.
party transfers controlled from the submit host and destination at the designated final data resting place. This uses either
Register replicas with the configured replica management system. Euryale permits other replica management systems besides RLS to be employed.
Clean-up the remote job directory, moving data products into the remote working directory. The clean-up job runs on the job manager for the
. The clean-up job is run synchronously through
Additionally, when encountering an error condition in the PRE script, Euryale runs the clean-up job, whenever the setup job has run successfully.
Before attempting to run workflows with Euryale, you may want to check the issues pointed out in this section.
The Euryale run-time system is written entirely in Perl. While we strive to be as compatible as possible, a number of modules are required for a successful setup:
This includes many modules like Carp, POSIX,
If you keep your WF database in PostGreSQL.
If you keep your WF database in MySQL.
If you keep your WF database in SQLite 2.
High-resolution time, sleep and related functions.
shows the Perl modules and versions required to run Euryale successfully. Note to self: This is fresh documentation; I may have missed some modules.
Euryale is configured through settings in a property file. Euryale is a mixed breed between Java and Perl. The Java portion of the
worlds, the VDS properties, and the Euryale
properties. The VDS properties reference guide is “
”, and the Euryale properties reference guide is “
This section repeats the introduction from the Euryale property guide, and emphasizes a couple of important properties. The
control the Euryale planner at run-time. Please note that the values rely on proper capitalization, unless explicitly noted otherwise.

Some properties can be made to rely on other properties. However, such a construction requires the dependent properties to be declared and visible. As a notation, the curly braces refer to the value of the named property. For instance,
means that the value depends on the value of the
any noted additions. You can use this notation to refer to other properties, though

of the substitutions are limited. Usually, you want to refer to a set of the standard system properties. Nesting is not allowed. Substitutions will only be done once. The following system properties are available:
The string that separates file name components.
The location of a directory for temporary files.
The name of the operating system, e.g. Linux.
The version of the OS kernel, e.g. 2.4.31
The operating system architecture, e.g. i386.
, or the appropriate entry from the account database.
Java always uses the account database.
: System properties provided by VDS to Perl.
properties only affect the Euryale planner, and certain portions of the VDS planning subsystem. All properties start with the letter "w", usually either "
" or "work". The Pegasus planner is not affected by properties declared in the
The following example provides a sensible set of properties to be set by the user property file. These properties use mostly non-default settings:
The above is an example only, and will not work for you!
Here are more useful configuration properties for Euryale:

By default, Euryale lets files stay wherever they are produced. If you specify a final output resource, all files marked as transferable will be copied to the final output site. The specification can either be a simple identifier. In this case, the identifier is assumed
site handle, and the site's GridFTP server will be determined from the site catalog. If the value starts with the “
” prefix, the output is a GridFTP server that is taken verbatim. Nevertheless, any path will be duplicated as necessary.
By default, Euryale will use the program called transfer to grid-copy files between sites.
. If the above property is set to anything (that evaluates to true in Perl), the program
has the advantage that it can try multiple sources for one file, in case a site goes down. It should be considered to provide transfers that are more robust.

For each job, a setup script is executed on the fork job manager. This script, when optimizing away transfers, because a required input file already exists at the site, places a link to the file into the job directory. Since the (transient) job directory and the work directory are thought to always (guaranteed) share the same file system, it may be less confusing to some applications, if hard links are employed. By default, if missing or value "false", Euryale works with soft links. Soft links are required, if the site uses AFS. A "true copy" option is not implemented.
The VDS is distributed with an application
that parses the kickstart record for failures of the remote site. If this option is set, and you should point it to your
, Euryale uses the specified program and
API to obtain the remote job's success. As a
will update the provenance tracking catalog (PTC). By default, if undefined, Euryale will use some internal logic to derive the remote job's success. However,
To overcome limits on the command line length, it is recommended to use relative paths wherever possible on the command line. Some application, like

, may require relative paths, because their computations may store file names within data products, to be referenced by subsequent steps. Only switch this property to false, if there is due cause. See also section

Some remote scheduling systems implement the notion of queues or projects. In order to enable jobs to run correctly on the site, the appropriate queue and project name can be supplied by configuration. However, we recommend that you use the profiles of “
” namespace with the site catalog instead.
The property value is a comma-separated list of key value pairs. The key is a site handle, and the value the queue name.
The property counts the number of retries that Euryale attempts before giving up on a job.
The miscellaneous items deal with temporary directories for temporary files, and the
thereafter. Please turn on unlinking unless you are debugging Euryale call-outs.
Profiles are a uniform abstraction of specific run-time environment options.
Profiles are propagated in four priority levels through the VDS
will set a VDS profile. The next component in the property key is the profile namespace. The fourth and final component in the property key is the profile key. Not all profiles are useful in Euryale:
Adds commands to a Condor submit file
Add configuration options to DAGMan’s DAG file.
Passes information to the site selector.
expects a certain directory hierarchy to find workflows and related files. We have found this hierarchy useful:
points to the base where the hierarchy starts (“b”).
is used as the next directory level (“v”).
is the directory level after that (“l”).
Together, these directories constitute the secondary key into the workflow database. They are necessary to uniquely identify any workflow and distinguish it from any other.
will automatically create the right directory hierarchy while maintaining the workflow database.
designates the base directory. It defaults to
if not specified – though we strongly encourage to specify a sane value.
Euryale exclusively works with pre-staged executables. The exception is
, the remote application starter. Depending on the submit file template, you can chose a pre-staged
, or a staged executable. The latter requires that the remote site has an operating system, architecture and (g
version compatible with our submit machine. Since this is rarely the case, we recommend using pre-staged
Euryale’s site model expects that the remote site layout
a file-system between gatekeeper (GK), worker node (WN) and storage element (SE).
Furthermore, the working directory configured for each job is expected to reside on this shared file system. This is the internal view used to generate
. The working directory, if appended to the base GridFTP URI, is the external view. The generation of
We are researching job and data scheduling models that will support reduced sharing of file systems. However, this is a complex problem.
Euryale uses the same set of catalogs as Pegasus. However,
uses the Perl API to access the catalogs.

There are three catalogs central to the planning process. The site catalog (SC) contains knowledge about the site layout, where directories are, what gatekeeper (GK) and GridFTP server to use. The transformation catalog (TC) contains knowledge about where applications are installed and what extra information they may require to invoke them. Finally, the replica catalog (RC) keeps track of files that were produced.
Properties are passed as set of property values with a common prefix to their respective handling catalog. The
property usually determines the implementation. It derives from the Perl module implementing the API for the said catalog.
This style designates a local replica catalog from RLS to store replicas.
A simplistic implementation using a local RDBMS table for replicas.
tool to use the VDS new RC API.
Each of the style has its own set of configuration properties (some may overlap).
The location of the LRC that will store all replicas.
In LRC style, it will also be queried for replicas.
The RLI that is queried for replicas.
This property overrides the setting of
to point to an alternative installation of Java.

This property overrides the location of the Globus tool
. Usually, there is no need to set this property.
This property overrides the location of the VDS tool
Usually, there is no need to set this property.
The contact URI used by DBI to access a RDBMS.
This is usually some string like “
For the simplistic DBI replica manager, you only need to create one table in your favorite RDBMS. The VDS database setup will
The VDS < 1.2 multi-column site catalog file (deprecated).
The VDS > 1.1 multi-line site catalog file.
The VDS > 1.1 site catalog as XML file (preferred).
refers to the location of the file that contains the site catalog.
The VDS < 1.3 multi-column transformation catalog file.
The VDS > 1.2 multi-column transformation catalog file.
An implementation accessing the RDBMS TC implementation via DBI.
In case of a file-based TC, the property
refers to the location of the TC file. In case of the RDBMS implementation, the regular VDS properties are parsed for the access data to the RDBMS
They may be overwritten in the constructor.
The workflow catalog does not come in different flavors.
its RDBMS access data has to be specified completely to enable Perl’s DBI module to access the workflow database.
property contains the base name of the Perl DBD module that implements a database. The other properties contain various access data to the RDBMS.
property has an indirect influence onto the rows in the workflow database, as explained in section

The site to run a compute job is selected dynamically at the point of time a compute job becomes run-able. The dynamic site selector is coded via a call-out to an external program. To talk to the site selector, a temporary file is generated, which contains simple key-value pairs:
The different keys strive to describe the job as best as possible to the site selector, and pass along a number of variables. Two multi-keys exist, the
occurs once for each GridFTP server of a site (yes, repeating the site handle if necessary), and
lists the required input files as LFNs for a job. Note that
only lists the GridFTP server hostname, and potentially a port, but no path component.

The prescript creates the above data in a temporary file. It executes the site selector application in a sub-process, passing the name of the temporary file as sole argument. The site selector application is specified in the workflow property
. The site selector in turn prints a string “
The chosen site should be a site handle from the
It must be a site handle that is known to the site catalog.
The version number of the protocol.
Logical name of the VDL transformation that represents the job.
VDL derivation name that was chosen for the job.
Unique ID for the job within the workflow.
Name of the workflow manager, currently “
The label given to the DAX file.
The modification time of the DAX file.
The unique job identifier, which is unique across all workflows
The wall time requirements presented by the job.
The disk space requirements of the job.
The name of the Virtual Organization the job belongs
A group within the Virtual Organization (arbitrary).
Lists one input LFN required by the job (multi-option).
: Typical keys exchanged with the site selector.

If a job is re-planned due to remote failure, bad sites are cached separately for each compute job, and omitted from the list of sites passed to the site selector. If no valid compute sites can be found, the prescript exits with an error.
The beauty of the external site selector is that it can be coded in any programming language that runs natively in the host environment. We recommend a scripting language with a
, Java classes execute natively with Linux, if the
kernel trappings are appropriately configured, see Linux kernel documentation.
A demo site selector, which randomly chooses from the given site set, is included in the distribution.
allow the integration of file popularity and monitoring feedback. If you intend to implement your own site selector in Perl, please refer to module

The information contained in the temporary communication file between Euryale logic and external site selector may be subject to extension in the future. A site selector must not stumble over, or warn about unknown keys in the exchanged file.
You probably don’t need to worry about the popularity manager. It is disabled by default.

Each compute job that ran to a successful completion will update the popularity manager for input files. To talk to the dynamically popularity manager, a temporary file is generated, which contains just the list of logical input filenames. Note that this file may be empty.

invokes the popularity manager with the site and the file of files as sole command line arguments. It is not expected to return anything. The default popularity manager is a no-operation. More elaborate popularity managers can update the popularity of a file for an advanced site selector, and thus asynchronously push hot-spot files to likely candidates.
There are two levels of conversion of a DAX file into the workflow DAG file and related submit files. The low-level tool
contains the conversion logic. At a higher level, the tool
, and employs configuration files for sensible defaults while maintaining a database of workflows.

The DAX file contains the abstract workflow description. The generation of DAX files is described elsewhere, and handled by the abstract planner. The DAX file, if generated from a VDC, is a build-style file containing knowledge how to build each intermediary product. However, the depth of the build can be limited. The DAX may also contain a forest in form of a disconnected graph, if multiple data products are requested simultaneously.
bridges between the VDS abstract level router and the Euryale concrete planner. While VDS is a pure Java system, Euryale is a Perl system. The
tool, as adaptor between the worlds, is controlled by two property files: The VDS properties, documented in section
, and the workflow property file, described in section
. Both property files are Java style.

The basic layout of each submit file is based on substitutions from a submit file template. The template contains a number of placeholders for different purposes. Through the template approach, the workflow can be easily adapted to different site requirements.
The template contains two kinds of
(variables), using a distinct mark-up for each.
itself. This point in the process is
Some variables may be filled with their final value, some with an empty string, and some with
logic. This is described in section
This variable represents the job’s command-line arguments. It may substitute to an empty value.
use. It translates into the name of a
Name of the Condor common user log file.
This file is shared by all Condor jobs. It should reside on a local file system.
Is the name of the DAG
This is the value, in XPath notation, of
from the abstract workflow. It is an arbitrary identifier for the workflow. We suggest
This is the last modification time of the DAX file.
definition identifier of a VDL Derivation.
This is the job identifier from the
attribute. Each id is unique to a workflow, but may occur in other workflows.
This is the depth of the job in the breadth first search tree. The value is taken from the DAX attribute
This is the value from the workflow property
It represents the maximum number of seconds a job is willing to wait in remote pending state. It defaults to 2 hours. A minimum of 10 minutes is enforced.
This option translates into a later substituted LFN, possibly empty. It derives from the DAX element

This is the name of the submit file without the “.sub” suffix.
This is the name of the file used as submit file template.
definition identifier of a VDL Transformation.
, and substitutions during the early replacement phase. However, a user rarely needs to concern
tool is a comfortable wrapper around
. It sanity checks a lot of the user’s environment before committing a workflow. It also manages a directory sub-tree to place workflows
are correctly set up, only the DAX file needs to be passed to

I have concretized your abstract workflow. The workflow has been entered into the workflow database with a state of "planned". The next step is to start or execute your workflow. The invocation required is
will tell you how to invoke
submit files needs to be executed by DAGMan. DAGMan will in turn invoke the
, which calls out the site selector
are several ones available. The interface is file-driven and
. The site selection logic selects one from the number of available sites.
The original set of site candidates is determined by the sites present in the site catalog (SC). The candidate set of sites is further limited by those sites in the transformation catalog (TC),
a site from a given list of candidates depending on a variety of strategies.
The simplest strategy is constant, always choosing the same site. This is a good selector for specifically testing out software due to the remote site guarantee. Usually you will
a site that you have easy access to. Also very simple, albeit not very efficient, are random-based strategies. Random strategies work well for trying out things.
Fancier algorithms, which take the presence of data at the destination site into account, or policies of remote sites, are presented separately by

. We research a class of simple observation-based site selectors. However, most advanced site selectors will require knowledge about intentions of each instance, requiring adequate protection from race conditions and other concurrency conflicts. These are discussed separately.
For any selected site, the submit file is finalized by substituting
holders. For the substitution, all VDS profiles are combined, with the VDL profiles at lowest

the PC profiles next, the TC profiles above that, and potential user profiles to override any lower priorities. Detailed overwrite, merge, or replace handling is not implemented - a higher priority profile always overwrites a lower priority value.
Input files are transferred always using submit-host-initiated

party transfers. If the transfers fail for any reason, re-planning takes place, marking the failed site as “bad” for the job, and only the current job. Propagating the knowledge between the independently planned jobs is researched, but so far showed no promise, and
with smarter site selectors. Should the
run out of sites to run, a fatal error is generated, which will terminate the
If the prescript ran successfully, DAGMan will start the compute job via Condor-G. Once the compute job finished, DAGMan will run the
, which parses the kickstart record, and transfers output files, if a central collection place is configured. Usually files are kept on the remote site. Having a central collection to put a replica
workflows. Should the site go down which stored the initial output, the replica in the central collector is still known.

determines that a transfer failed, or the job failed, the post script will fail, and DAGMan will attempt to run the job again, up to the number of user-configurable retries, starting with the prescript. The postscript also tags the failed site as “bad” to keep the site selector from choosing it again when re-planning.
This value is substituted with the working directory at the remote site. It is taken from the pool/
Each job runs in its own job directory. This value represents the job directory underneath the WORKDIR that a job will run in.
This value is the site handle from the site catalog. It uniquely identifies the site in the VDS catalogs.
is unique for the workflows, and with a very high probability even across multiple workflows. However, the identifier remains keeps its value, if a job is re-planned.
Each job must declare an upper boundary on its computation time. The wall time is also required for the job monitor to find misbehaving jobs and sites.
This is the upper boundary of require disk space.
This is the location of the remote kickstart application. It is taken from the site catalog’s
Will be substituted with the logical transformation name.
The name may contain colons, like any
Will be substituted with the remote application’s location.
Euryale only works with out-of-band pre-staged executables.
This is replaced with the chosen
for the remote site. It derives from the pool/
Should a job declare that it wants to track its own
, this string will convert into the appropriate kickstart invocation arguments.
This value will be created from “
This is similar to the GLOBUSRSL. However, if present, it will generate the Globus RSL with a prefix of “
= “. If no RSL values were found, nothing, not even an empty line, is generated.
This value contains additional settings from the “condor” namespace profiles.
This value will extract remote environment settings from the “
This special key substitutes each LFN xxx with its SFN.
This special key substitutes the environment value of xxx from the submit host’s local environment.
a workflow, you must consider leaf input files. These are files that are required to exist at some site, and their replicas be known to a replica manager.

shows a simple workflow. In this workflow, LFN1 and LFN3 are leaf input files. No productions exist to generate them. Thus, their replica locations must be registered with a replica manager before a workflow is started. Otherwise, the workflow cannot succeed.
If you want to check manually for input files, extract all
/filename elements. Those with an attribute “link” of “input” designate leaf input files for the given workflows. The “
” attribute shows you the LFN that must be known to your replica manager. For VDS-generated DAX files, you can use
tool will check, among other things, that all leaf input files are known to your configured replica manager. It is more convenient, because it will check your replica manager for
for the existence of all necessary files. It will complain, if something is missing:
All is well that ends well.
for very large workflows can be expensive, as the XML representation of the workflow is kept in main memory.
There is one prime rule for Euryale workflows:
While it may appear to work, depending on your workflow, you may overtax the resources on your submit system. VDS ships with the
sets suitable throttles for DAGMan. While the throttles default to numbers we found reasonable, a user can configure them.
tool itself is a wrapper around
. Additionally, it manages workflow state, and starts a
daemon to watch over your workflow. The workflow monitor

kills misbehaving jobs while simultaneously maintaining the state of each job in the workflow database. It will also update the workflow database with the DAGMan’s exit code, once it detects that DAGMan is gone.
Checking all your submit files for log file names.
File for submitting this DAG to
Log of Condor library debug messages : /work/ivdgl1/black-diamond/run0031/black-diamond-0.dag.lib.out
for all jobs of this DAG: /tmp/black-diamond-50999.log
I have started your workflow, committed it to DAGMan, and updated its
in the work database. A separate daemon was started to collect
about the progress of the workflow. The job state will soon
visible. Your workflow runs in base directory

For now, the output will still contain some amount of debug message. However, in the end, it tells you which directory to change into, if you want to watch the workflow closely. That base directory will contain the high-level files pertaining to your workflow.
Pre- and postscript protocol verbosely what they are doing in a per job file with suffix “.
also logs certain information of global interest into a common, shared file “
”. DAGMan maintains its own debug file. Condor tracks job state in the common user log file. The workflow monitor
Each job maintains a debug file in the same directory where the submit file resides. It uses the same base name, but a suffix “.
”. Usually, the job debug files, albeit
, contain the best clues why a job fails.
The structure of the job debug file is fixed in the first few columns to enable good parsing:
It starts with an ISO 8601 compliant local time stamp with millisecond extension. The time zone is omitted, though.
The next column contains the bracketed process ID of the writer. This
the pre- or post script which is currently active.
column contains a tag “PRE” to indicate a
. No other scripts should write to this debug file.

After follows a free format message. Some messages may be prefixed with Perl module identifiers or recognizable strings to indicate the urgency of the message. However, there is no coherent format to the rest of the line.
20050916T154049.566 [32539] PRE: done with submit file ID000001.sub
write important message to a shared file “
”. This file resides in the same directory where the DAG file resides. Since the access is shared between concurrent instances, only few important
are written to this file. If a workflow fails, the first clue is usually found here.
The log file contains several columns:
The first column contains a simple 3-character tag. The purpose of this tag is to enable quick searches using
” marks the reason for a fatal failure.
an ISO 8601 compliant local time stamp with millisecond extension. The time zone is omitted, though
The next column contains the bracketed process ID of the writer. This
the pre- or post script which is currently active.
column contains the job identifier. Each identifier is only unique within the workflow it belongs
The next column contains a tag “PRE” to indicate a
. No other scripts should write to this debug file.

After follows a free format message. Some messages may be prefixed with Perl module identifiers or recognizable strings to indicate the urgency of the message. However, there is no coherent format to the rest of the line.

The common log can be used to compute things like compute time, number of transfers, etc. One such file is associated with each workflow. For reasons of performance, the information in this file is few and restricted. While it may contain some clues about reasons for failure, one should always check the failing job’s debug file for specifics. An example:
20050916T154054.294 [32539] ID000001 PRE: ran terminable.uchicago.edu:2120/jobmanager-fork -s ID000001.setup.sh in 3.759 s
Sometimes, rarely but not impossible, DAGMan may get confused by the messages it detects. If the Euryale-related log files do not yield
why a workflow failed, the DAGMan debug file may. It usually resides in a file with the same name as the DAG file plus the suffix “.
9/16 15:40:59 Event: ULOG_SUBMIT for Condor Job ID000001 (27.0)
Pre Queued Post Ready Un-Ready Failed
9/16 15:41:09 Event: ULOG_GLOBUS_SUBMIT for Condor Job ID000001 (27.0)
9/16 15:41:09 Event: ULOG_JOB_HELD for Condor Job ID000001 (27.0)
9/16 15:41:44 Event: ULOG_JOB_RELEASED for Condor Job ID000001 (27.0)
9/16 15:46:14 Event: ULOG_GLOBUS_SUBMIT for Condor Job ID000001 (27.0)
9/16 15:46:14 Event: ULOG_JOB_HELD for Condor Job ID000001 (27.0)
9/16 15:46:44 Event: ULOG_JOB_RELEASED for Condor Job ID000001 (27.0)
The lines containing the HELD and RELEASED show that something fishy was going with this workflow. The SIGUSR1 indicates that the user chose to terminate DAGMan using
The final exit code on the last line is what the workflow monitor
will record as status of the workflow before exiting itself.
Here is another DAGMan debug file, indicating an actual problem with DAGMan:
9/15 18:24:31 Max PRE scripts (20) already running; deferring PRE script of Job ID000135
9/15 18:24:41 Event: ULOG_JOB_TERMINATED for Condor Job ID000092 (13323.0)
9/15 18:24:41 EVENT ERROR: job 13323.0.0 ended; total end
18:24:41 WARNING: bad event here may indicate a serious bug in Condor -- beware!
9/15 18:24:41 Aborting DAG because of bad event (EVENT ERROR: job 13323.0.0 ended; total end
This DAGMan stumbled over duplicated “job terminated” events in Condor’s common user log file. DAGMan can be told to ignore such event duplications, which may happen due to race conditions.
Condor writes its own log file, with one paragraph entry for each entry. If you use Perl to parse the records, you must set your input record separator $/ to “\n…\n”.

Euryale puts the log file into a local temporary file system. The workflow monitor, upon start-up, places a symbolic link to the temporary file system file into the directory where the DAG file resides. It replaces the symbolic link with the true file once the workflow has finished.
Globus error 43: the job manager failed to stage the executable
Globus error 43: the job manager failed to stage the executable
(027.000.000) 09/16 15:47:48 Job was aborted by the user.
The above log file excerpt contains Globus errors 43. The submit file for job ID000001 contained instructions to transfer the executable from the submit machine to the remote host, but the executable
exist where indicated. Condor retried the submission a
time, still without success. Eventually, the user decided to terminate the workflow.
reports its own progress and failures into a file “
”. The file is a simple format, started by an ISO 8601 local time stamp without time zone but millisecond extension. The next column contains a bracket line number from DAGMan’s debug file that the
daemon parses. Finally, the rest of the line constitutes the log message.
20050916T154114.614 [64]: job ID000001 is planned for site terminable
20050916T154637.674 [67]: job ID000001 is planned for site terminable
maintains the current state of each job in the workflow database, the transition of job states is logged into the “
” file. It resides in the same directory the DAG file is located
The file has at least three columns, but no more than
column is a UTC time stamp, seconds since epoch.
column provides the job id within the workflow. The special identifier “INTERNAL” protocols event messages from the workflow monitor.
column for jobs is the symbolic job state. The job states are mostly taken from Condor.
If available, the Condor ID of the job.
If available, the site handle where the job was intended to run.
If available, the wall time in seconds.
Euryale can use WS-GRAM for job submissions. In this case, it is required to set up the site catalog correctly. Only the XML site catalog format is capable of handling GT4 sites correctly. The
with such a set-up, using delegations achieves extra performance. While Condor-G maintains a delegation cache for the duration of the grid manager, the Euryale job
requires delegation before reaching the Condor-G step. Thus, if delegation is desired, a
needs to be started before the workflow. If the daemon is detected and active, all remote delegations will be handled by it. Furthermore, Condor-G is told about existing delegations.
While initial numbers suggested a 20% speed-up by using delegations, recent versions of Globus and Condor do not appear to achieve these numbers any longer.
Condor has a built-in limit of
(4096) bytes for the arguments length in the submit file, as mandated by POSIX. However, Linux permits 128k, and many modern

permit a larger number. This rather irksome feature of Condor can be overcome by a new prototypical mode in Euryale and recent versions of kickstart releases in "invoke" mode. In invoke mode, the argument vector is shipped in a file to the remote site, and read by kickstart.
Euryale automatically detects, if a command-line is longer than 4k, and activates invoke mode. However, due to the transfer overhead,
shorter than 4k are kept without invoke mode. Currently, the property
controls the cut-off point. If set to a very small non-negative integer, invoke mode will always be used. If set above 4k, Condor will fail at submit time.
